I'm Tony, CEO at Medium. First of all, welcome and thank you for joining the millions of people who deepen their understanding of the world by reading and writing stories here. By creating a free account, you are joining a global community that values the expertise, words, and experiences of human writers.

Below, we've made you a guide to get the most out of Medium with your new account.

Thank you for being here. Thank you for reading. I look forward to seeing you on Medium.

Tony Stubblebine
CEO, Medium

This interactive guide walks you through everything you need to get the best out of your free Medium account. A few highlights:

5.subject: Welcome to Product Hunt Dev
5.body:
🛸

Hello there!

Welcome to Product Hunt Dev, a newsletter all about developer tools and random, cool engineering stuff.

Soon you’ll receive your first digest, and it’ll hit your inbox every Wednesday(ish) after that. Here’s what you can expect:

🛠️ Developer Tools: We’ll dive into the top and trending tools you can’t miss

🗞 AI headlines: Keep up to date on what’s new and what devs should know

🤯 Cool stuff: Weird or wonderful stories from the greater world of engineering

A few pointers to enhance your experience:

Gmail users: Ensure our emails land straight into your primary inbox. On mobile, hit the 3 dots at the top right corner, select "Move to" then "Primary". On desktop, simply drag and drop our email into the "Primary" tab.

Apple Mail users: Tap our email address at the top and select “Add to VIPs”.

For all other email platforms, follow these instructions.

See you in your inbox! 👋

The Product Hunt team

I write The Download (https://forms.technologyreview.com/newsletters/briefing-the-download/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.onboarding)  at MIT Technology Review, our daily newsletter on the latest, most exciting goings-on from the world of emerging technology. Thanks for joining me! Our aim is to help you navigate through the news, cut through the hype, and tell you about what really matters (plus, we hope, entertain you a bit along the way). My goal is for this to be the only newsletter in tech you need to read.

Thanks for reading. I’d love to hear what you think about The Download, and if you enjoy it, please don’t hesitate to pass along our sign-up page (https://forms.technologyreview.com/newsletters/briefing-the-download/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.onboarding) to anyone you think might also benefit from being a part of our newsletter community.

13.subject: Don’t
13.body:
Issue #224: your thoughts on the Great Barrington Declaration, and a useful quote
The Medium Newsletter (https://medium.com/blog/newsletters/the-medium-newsletter?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733744478094-newsletter.v3-15f753907972------------------------b6bf26c9_5a48_4735_ba36_a58fa1559513--------bf3f56c7deec)

A newsletter by The Medium Blog (https://medium.com/blog?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733744478094-newsletter.v3-15f753907972------------------------b6bf26c9_5a48_4735_ba36_a58fa1559513--------bf3f56c7deec)

  ∙  
December 9, 2024  ∙  
4 min read  ∙  
View on Medium (https://medium.com/blog/75888216b93f?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733744478094-newsletter.v3-15f753907972------------------------b6bf26c9_5a48_4735_ba36_a58fa1559513--------bf3f56c7deec)

Don't fear failure. Fear ignorance.
👋 Welcome back to the Medium Newsletter
Issue #224: your thoughts on the Great Barrington Declaration, and a useful quote
Here are three pieces of practical wisdom to take with you this week:
Your biggest fear should not be failure; it should be ignorance. In the words of Meta CTO Andrew Bosworth, the downfall of most organizations is "widespread acceptance of the wrong idea (http://redirect.medium.systems/r--_qaSKpUc0?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733744478094-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-75888216b93f-----------------------b6bf26c9_5a48_4735_ba36_a58fa1559513--------bf3f56c7deec)
" - misinformed, overconfident assumptions that become so familiar they go unquestioned. This applies on a personal level, too. One way to combat it: seek out, encourage, and reward dissent.
A singleminded passion might sustain you briefly, but when it flames out, as novelist and marketer Felicia C. Sullivan (https://medium.com/u/dcc7ed6948f1)
 recommends, think of your life as a series of rooms you can dip in and out of. Build a "house of fulfillment (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-2LLMplOXdr?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733744478094-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-75888216b93f-----------------------b6bf26c9_5a48_4735_ba36_a58fa1559513--------bf3f56c7deec)
" that can sustain you over time, bigger than any individual pursuit.
The top 10 movies of 2024 are all sequels, if you count Wicked as a sequel. Reasons for this are cultural and economic: The rise of streaming makes studios more risk-averse because they can no longer earn long-tail revenue on VHS and DVD sales. More data = more obsession with data, and a preoccupation with replicating hits. Rebranding existing IP is cheap and nostalgia sells. Ask yourself: How often are you watching/reading/listening to stories that feel new and challenging v. stories that feel familiar? (Ted Gioia)

- Harris Sockel
Also today: Your thoughts on the Great Barrington Declaration
Last week, we sent a newsletter about the Great Barrington Declaration, a 2020 open letter by three epidemiologists arguing blanket Covid lockdowns would do more harm than good. Many of you responded thoughtfully, disagreeing or adding nuance to the conversation. We love nothing more than reasoned disagreement. Here are a few responses that stood out to us:
In retrospect, some of the premises laid down in the GDB actually hold true. There was an impact on mental health, and it was difficult to get access to general medical procedures due to the lockdown.
The term 'herd immunity' is usually misunderstood. As defined in the GBD, it implies a steady rate of infection (and cure), similar to what we see with influenza. But the general public took it to mean that we'll become immune to the corona virus, which can never happen as the virus always mutates. 
- S Chakraborty
I get the point you make in this article, and generally agree with it - except that the pushback on the GBD wasn't overblown. The GBD made some claims that have been proven false, and the anti-vax, anti-shutdown, anti-public health political right immediately adopted a black-and-white approach, acting as if they knew what was right and wrong, and ignoring the fact that public health authorities were making the best decisions they could under circumstances of uncertainty. They dishonestly framed the issue in terms of good vs. evil, and that is what the pushback was against.
 - Robert Kantner
Frankly, I can't see why you would want to elevate people with a track record of being wrong over those who have a track record of being right. Or how you would think you could justify doing so by saying 'well, there was a lot of fear and uncertainty at the time'. Surely that's all the more reason to back those who made good decisions despite the challenging circumstances? 
- Mark S
You strike the right tone of intellectual curiosity, neutrality, and just practical common sense. Something that has eroded in the last eight years. Nice to see an effort to stimulate healthy, informative dialogue rather than continue the campaign of painting those with a differing opinion as evil. 
 - Gpanah in an email to tips@medium.com

🎁 One more story: on giving
Six years ago, Kristine Levine (https://medium.com/u/885e14633a5e)
 published a Medium essay (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-4uWLrl4hmc?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733744478094-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-75888216b93f-----------------------b6bf26c9_5a48_4735_ba36_a58fa1559513--------bf3f56c7deec)
 reflecting on the poverty and hunger she experienced as a child. Levine's mom was unemployed, and they rarely ate dinner. One night, they wandered the neighborhood, knocking on doors until a neighbor answered. She immediately packed up her entire dinner table and handed it to them. Levine has been thinking about that moment her entire life - not just because of what it meant to her and her mother, but because it contains a lesson that applies to so much in life. "When you give the best you have to someone in need," Levine writes, "it translates into something much deeper to the receiver. It means that they are worthy."
···
Deepen your understanding every day with the Medium Newsletter. Sign up here.
Edited and produced by Scott Lamb & Carly Rose Gillis
Questions, feedback, or story suggestions? Email us: tips@medium.com
Like what you see in this newsletter but not already a Medium member? Read without limits or ads, fund great writers, and join a community that believes in human storytelling.

From The Medium Newsletter

14.subject: Reverse String
14.body:
[The Daily Byte](http://thedailybyte.dev)

Good morning,

Need help with yesterday's problem? [Start getting solutions.](http://thedailybyte.dev/plan#email=clutterfreemailtest@gmail.com)

Today's Byte

Welcome to your first of many daily bytes! We are starting with a strings problem and we strongly recommend you find the time each day to solve these problems. It is important to not just solve them in your head but actually whip out your favorite editor/IDE and write a function and use the test cases supplied in the question to check your work. Getting yourself to actually write down the solutions will go a long way to ensuring you are thinking through all the edge cases as well as any space/time complexities.
This question is asked by Google. Given a string, reverse all of its characters and return the resulting string.
Ex: Given the following strings...
“Cat”, return “taC”
“The Daily Byte”, return "etyB yliaD ehT”
“civic”, return “civic”

Thanks,
The Daily Byte

---

[Newsletter](http://thedailybyte.dev/ref/developing) that fills the gaps for engineers who don’t have dedicated mentorship in 5 minutes or less. Written by a Staff Software Engineer @ Instagram
---

15.subject: The world’s next big environmental problem could come from space
15.sender: The Download from MIT Technology Review <newsletters@technologyreview.com>
15.body:
OpenAI’s “12 days of shipmas” tell us a lot about the AI arms race

In partnership with Michigan Economic Development Corporation (https://www.michiganbusiness.org/?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID)
https://ter.li/TR15-2024-Download?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID
Subscribe & Save 25% (https://ter.li/TR15-2024-Download?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID)


**
The Download
------------------------------------------------------------


** Your daily dose of what’s up in emerging technology
------------------------------------------------------------


** By Charlotte Jee • 12.09.24
------------------------------------------------------------

Hello! Today: satellites burning up in the atmosphere could potentially alter the climate—but we don’t yet know how big a problem they pose. Also: what OpenAI’s frantic release schedule tells us about the state of AI right now.

https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/12/09/1108076/satellite-reentry-atmospheric-pollution/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-09-2024&mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID


** The world’s next big environmental problem could come from space
------------------------------------------------------------
In September, a unique chase took place in the skies above Easter Island. From a rented jet, a team of researchers captured a satellite’s last moments as it fell out of space and blazed into ash across the sky, using cameras and scientific equipment. Their hope was to gather priceless insights into the physical and chemical processes that occur when satellites burn up as they fall to Earth at the end of their missions.

This kind of study is growing more urgent. The number of satellites in the sky is rapidly rising—with a tenfold increase forecast by the end of the decade. Letting these satellites burn up in the atmosphere at the end of their lives helps keep the quantity of space junk to a minimum. But doing so deposits satellite ash in the Earth’s atmosphere. This metallic ash could potentially alter the climate, and we don’t yet know how serious the problem is likely to be. Read the full story (https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/12/09/1108076/satellite-reentry-atmospheric-pollution/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-09-2024&mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

—Tereza Pultarova
https://ter.li/TR10SneakPeek-Download25?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID


** OpenAI’s “12 days of shipmas” tell us a lot about the AI arms race
------------------------------------------------------------

Last week, OpenAI announced what it calls the 12 days of OpenAI, or 12 days of shipmas. On December 4, CEO Sam Altman took to X to announce that the company would be “doing 12 days of openai. each weekday, we will have a livestream with a launch or demo, some big ones and some stocking stuffers.”

The company will livestream about new products every morning for 12 business days in a row during December. It’s an impressive-sounding (and media-savvy) schedule, to be sure. But it also speaks to how tight the race between the AI bigs has become, and also how much OpenAI is scrambling to build more revenue. Read the full story (https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/12/09/1108136/openais-12-days-of-shipmas-tell-us-a-lot-about-the-ai-arms-race/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-09-2024&mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

—Mat Honan
This story originally appeared in The Debrief with Mat Honan, our weekly take on what’s really going on behind the biggest tech headlines. The story is subscriber-only so nab a subscription (https://www.technologyreview.com/subscribe/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-09-2024&mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) , if you haven’t already! Or you can sign up (https://forms.technologyreview.com/newsletters/the-debrief-with-mat-honan/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-09-2024&mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) to the newsletter for free to get the next edition in your inbox on Friday.

In partnership with Michigan Economic Development Corporation (https://www.michiganbusiness.org/?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) https://www.michiganbusiness.org/?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID
https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/09/23/1103998/addressing-climate-change-impacts/?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID

Is Your Business Considering the Risks of Climate Change? (https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/09/23/1103998/addressing-climate-change-impacts/?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID)

Extreme weather and rising operational costs are forcing companies to adapt. In a new report analyzing the business impacts of climate change, 81% of executives say climate planning is critical to their operations, and a staggering 75% of U.S. businesses have considered relocating due to climate risks. While no region is immune to climate change, 42% of executives say they believe the Midwest is the least exposed to climate risks. Read the full report on addressing climate change impacts (https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/09/23/1103998/addressing-climate-change-impacts/?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) .


** The must-reads
------------------------------------------------------------
I’ve combed the internet to find you today’s most fun/important/scary/fascinating stories about technology.

1 The USDA is launching a national program to test milk for bird flu
A full nine months after the current outbreak was first detected in dairy cows. (STAT (https://www.statnews.com/2024/12/06/usda-launching-mandatory-national-milk-testing-program-to-track-h5n1-flu-outbreak-in-cows?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) )
+ The risk of a bird flu pandemic is rising. (MIT Technology Review (https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/11/29/1107552/risk-of-bird-flu-pandemic-rising/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-09-2024&mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) )

2 Here’s what sets OpenAI’s new models apart
They’re shifting from predicting to reasoning, which could be a huge deal. (The Atlantic (https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2024/12/openai-o1-reasoning-models/680906?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)
+ Regardless of whether capabilities are slowing, AI’s impact is only poised to grow. (Vox (https://www.vox.com/future-perfect/389997/artificial-intelligence-openai-google-microsoft-chatgpt-progress-scaling?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) )
+ It may be comforting to dismiss AI as hype—but it misses the point. (Platformer (https://www.platformer.news/ai-skeptics-gary-marcus-curve-conference/?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) )

3 A federal appeals court has upheld the US TikTok ban
But what happens next is anyone’s guess. (WSJ (https://www.wsj.com/politics/policy/tik-tok-congress-ban-court-ruling-1f0d6837?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)
+ Whether TikTok is banned or not, the actions against it have had a big impact. (MIT Technology Review (https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/05/01/1091951/tiktok-ban-chinese-companies-political/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-09-2024&mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) )

4 Top internet sleuths are sitting out the hunt for the UnitedHealthcare CEO killer
In fact, some are even criticizing people who are trying to help. (NBC (https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/internet/internet-sleuths-say-wont-help-find-unitedhealthcare-ceo-suspect-rcna183228?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) )
+ Why so many Americans are at best indifferent to this particular murder. (New Yorker (https://www.newyorker.com/news/the-lede/what-the-murder-of-the-unitedhealthcare-ceo-brian-thompson-means-to-america?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)

5 Schools are attempting to stop teens self-harming before they even try
The AI tools they’re adopting could be doing far more damage than help, though. (NYT (https://www.nytimes.com/2024/12/09/health/suicide-monitoring-software-schools.html?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)

6 China is building its own Starlink system
The Qianfan constellation could eventually grow to nearly 14,000 satellites. (The Economist (https://www.economist.com/science-and-technology/2024/12/06/why-china-is-building-a-starlink-system-of-its-own?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)
+ The end of the ISS will usher in a more commercialized future in space. (The Verge (https://www.theverge.com/2024/12/7/24314191/iss-end-2030-commercial-space-station-mars-moon?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) )

7 This was an exciting year for superconductors
Superconductivity—the flow of electric current with no resistance—was discovered in three new materials. (Quanta (https://www.quantamagazine.org/exotic-new-superconductors-delight-and-confound-20241206/?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)

8 Meet the world’s least productive programmers
It seems a small minority of disillusioned ‘ghost engineers’ do pretty much no work at all. (WP (https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2024/12/08/ghost-engineers-programming-productivity-coding/?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)

9 Why people are turning their backs on dating apps
There’s a large degree of fatigue, and a feeling that they’re somehow detached from reality. (The Guardian (https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2024/dec/08/it-feels-like-admin-why-are-people-falling-out-of-love-with-dating-apps?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) )

10 Fake snacks are racking up millions of views on Instagram 🍿
There’s even a word for this trend: snackfishing. (Wired (https://www.wired.com/story/snackfishing-fake-viral-food-clear-ketchup/?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)


** Quote of the day
------------------------------------------------------------
------------------------------------------------------------


** “I think Twitter and now X is like a crack addiction for him, though. He is clearly chasing a particular hit all the time and he has ended up self-radicalising himself with the platform he has purchased.”
------------------------------------------------------------
—A former Twitter employee in London tells The Guardian (https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2024/dec/07/money-lawyers-or-boosting-farage-on-x-how-elon-musk-could-affect-uk-politics?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) how Elon Musk has changed since he purchased the platform.


** The big story
------------------------------------------------------------
https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/01/03/1084734/sublime-systems-cement-climate-change-carbon-footprint/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-09-2024&mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID


** How electricity could help tackle a surprising climate villain
------------------------------------------------------------
January 2024

Cement is used to build everything from roads and buildings to dams and basement floors. But it’s also a climate threat. Cement production accounts for more than 7% of global carbon dioxide emissions—more than sectors like aviation, shipping, or landfills.

One solution to this climate catastrophe might be coursing through the pipes at Sublime Systems. The startup is developing an entirely new way to make cement. Instead of heating crushed-up rocks in lava-hot kilns, Sublime’s technology zaps them in water with electricity, kicking off chemical reactions that form the main ingredients in its cement.

But it faces huge challenges: competing with established industry players, and persuading builders to use its materials in the first place. Read the full story (https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/01/03/1084734/sublime-systems-cement-climate-change-carbon-footprint/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-09-2024&mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

—Casey Crownhart


** We can still have nice things
------------------------------------------------------------

A place for comfort, fun and distraction to brighten up your day. (Got any ideas? Drop me a line (mailto:rhiannon.williams@technologyreview.com)  or tweet 'em at me (https://twitter.com/yannon_?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) .)

+ Who will be the Lord of Misrule (https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2024/dec/08/ten-dark-winter-rituals?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) in your household this Christmas?
+ People’s Wikipedia (https://thehustle.co/news/what-people-read-on-wikipedia-in-2024?hubs_content=thehustle.co%2F&hubs_content-cta=What%20people%20read%20on%20Wikipedia%20in%202024&mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) browsing data always makes for interesting reading.
+ Wait, so we’ve been mispronouncing these words (https://news.sky.com/story/these-are-the-words-you-have-been-saying-incorrectly-all-year-13266719?mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) all along? (Apart from espresso, c’mon)
+ The Muppet Christmas Carol (https://www.tiktok.com/@towlo85/video/7444093163666410785?_r=1&_t=8rzNA5mZXYO&mc_cid=5b3db3b17e&mc_eid=UNIQID) might just be the greatest festive film.

17.subject: 😸 Sleep as a service
17.body:
Your own Jarvis

Product Hunt ( https://www.producthunt.com/?utm_campaign=35832_2024-12-09&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=Daily+Digest )

Monday, Dec 09
The Leaderboard

Happy Monday legends! Welcome back to another fine edition
of the Leaderboard. Today, we have a personal Jarvis-like
assistant, an app to help all you new parents get some
well-deserved sleep, and an AirBnB built for Nomads. Let's dive
in.

Your own Jarvis ( )

Martin: ( https://www.producthunt.com/posts/martin-3?utm_campaign=35832_2024-12-09&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=Daily+Digest&utm_term=editorial ) An AI personal assistant

Eventually, I’d imagine our AI assistants will be a bit like P.G.
Wodehouse’s Jeeves — ever-present, extremely competent, and
slightly bemused at their masters’ incompetence. Martin seems
like a good first step in that direction. You can call, text,
email or slack it and ask it to handle basic scheduling tasks.
Right now, the additional friction required to get used to the UI
will probably dissuade all but the most enthusiastic early
adopters. But once Martin can start reliably responding to
emails, scheduling appointments, and summarizing our social media
feeds? Then we’ll see a real human-computer interaction paradigm
shift.

Sanjana Friedman ( https://www.producthunt.com/@sanjanaf )

Sanjana Friedman
Head of Content @ Product Hunt ( https://www.producthunt.com/@sanjanaf )

Sleep as a service ( )

Remy AI: ( https://www.producthunt.com/posts/remy-ai?utm_campaign=35832_2024-12-09&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=Daily+Digest&utm_term=editorial ) An AI sleep and recovery assistant

There's much to love about Remy's launch today. From the clever
use of an AI talking via its maker's comment to the ability to
predict your melatonin and cortisol daily peaks. Remy seems like
a refreshing and well packaged take in a crowded space. My
favorite part? It started as a Telegram bot that evolved into a
full product based on community useage and feedback. In a world
where folks are launching Telegram bots as products, this seems
like the right approach - test within a community first, then
spin the bot out as a full product that offers more that what's
capable within Telegram. Now g2g, Remy is waiting to tuck me in

Gabe Perez ( https://www.producthunt.com/@gabe )

Gabe Perez
Head of Product Curation @ Product Hunt ( https://www.producthunt.com/@gabe )

Collaborative travel ( )

Airmeet: ( https://www.producthunt.com/posts/airmeet-2?utm_campaign=35832_2024-12-09&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=Daily+Digest&utm_term=editorial ) Coliving on demand

Airmeet feels like Airbnb’s social cousin—less about booking,
more about bonding. The idea? Turn dream stays into affordable
realities by teaming up with like-minded strangers. Foodies in
Spain? Night owls in Bali? You pick the vibe, split the villa,
and live the good life. But here’s my question: Why not just use
Airbnb and wrangle a group chat myself? I guess the magic here is
the curation—finding people you’d actually want to share a fridge
with. If it nails that, Airmeet could make solo travel a lot
less, well, solo, and a lot more fun — especially for nomads.

Aaron O'Leary ( https://www.producthunt.com/@aaronoleary )

Aaron O'Leary
Content @ Product Hunt ( https://www.producthunt.com/@aaronoleary )

21.subject: The second Gilded Age: Why the 2020s feel like the 1890s
21.body:
Issue #225: An ode to details + the Three-Round Rule of Editing
The Medium Newsletter (https://medium.com/blog/newsletters/the-medium-newsletter?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972------------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)

A newsletter by The Medium Blog (https://medium.com/blog?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972------------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)

  ∙  
December 10, 2024  ∙  
3 min read  ∙  
View on Medium (https://medium.com/blog/ae53b2a22bf2?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972------------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)

The second Gilded Age: Why the 2020s feel like the 1890s
👋 Welcome back to the Medium Newsletter
Issue #225: an ode to details + the Three-Round Rule of Editing
Let's rewind to 1876. On Valentine's Day that year, a quirky inventor in Boston submitted a patent for what would become the phone. He wasn't the only one-Elisha Gray submitted a similar patent the same day, and contested Bell's (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-ECdFs04nsm?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
. Patents in the late 1800s grew nearly 400% (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-5w_vJ7-M5E?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
 (and so did patent litigation (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-_y629qjH2X?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
).
That was the beginning of the Gilded Age (roughly 1870 to 1900 in the U.S.), a period of explosive economic, cultural, and technological change in nearly every dimension of life. New tools changed how we connect, communicate, and make art: the telephone, phonograph, trains, cars, the Kodak camera (https://medium.com/the-atlantic/the-rise-and-fall-of-an-american-tech-giant-68399466bedf?sk=v2%2F4632560a-2261-4340-87c2-869ac59ad46f)
. The creators of these tools (or those who built infrastructure to help them scale) lived in Gothic villas with armies of staff that insulated them from the world. The top 4,000 families in the U.S. were as rich as everyone else combined (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-zPxN03GC1y?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
.
Today, instead of the telephone and phonograph, we have lightning-fast user-generated video and AI-enhanced art. Instead of The Breakers (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-atI04tjQSG?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
, industry titans live in hyperminimalist glass-and-concrete mansions in northern California. Global income inequality is even more pronounced (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-VMQFcdJ_Pf?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
 than it was 150 years ago. In the U.S., income inequality is higher than in any of the G7 nations (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-IO7-tC9XMq?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
. The divide between the 
Mark Twain, who coined the term "Gilded Age" in an 1870s satirical novel, chose the word (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-K4GKDV0WgV?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
 "gilded" instead of "gold" to signify that the sheen was only skin deep, like body paint instead of lasting wealth. Underneath the surface of progress and glamour, a lot of people were unhappy and angry. Anarchists expressed their rage by throwing bombs and assassinating industrialists (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-gslcdkl3SI?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
. Railroad workers went on strike, and so did farmers.
The parallels (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-D8EnZzdvHY?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
 between then and now, once you're aware of them, are hard to unsee: lookalike contests (https://medium.com/@refreshingtime/the-myth-of-decorum-9d597fcc97ae)
 (a form of cheap entertainment that imitates/idolizes people in power) in place of small-town Vaudeville impersonators (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-0PjTESZPcO?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
; the assassination of UnitedHealth CEO Brian Thompson and its revolution-tinged fallout (https://medium.com/@francesachiu/party-like-its-1789-reactions-to-the-death-of-the-unitedhealthcare-ceo-d8f80458b7cd?sk=v2%2F0ad78838-8fb9-42f7-9c4b-868d908f5451)
, an echo of the attempted assassination of anti-union steel magnate Henry Clay Frick (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-FlzjjRhhhb?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
 by a labor activist; the rise of labor unions (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-fG7e9KvQH-?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
 - which some credit as helping to end the first Gilded Age (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-lOSfx9D42Q?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
.
I'm borrowing some of this argument from sociologist Zeynep Tufekci (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-FKnTbCpsqw?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
, but I've been thinking about it a lot lately. Is this what it feels like to live through the second Gilded Age?
- Harris Sockel
⚡ 1 story, 1 sentence
ChatGPT is known to evade questions about names appearing on U.S. terrorism watch lists (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-cb8bQ35pRP?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
. (Cassie Kozyrkov (https://medium.com/u/2fccb851bb5e)
)
The idea that "55% of communication is nonverbal" took off 20 years ago, but it's a misinterpretation of experiment results - and as it turns out, the importance of nonverbal communication changes based on context (https://medium.com/the-springboard/scientific-smoke-and-mirrors-when-research-breaks-its-own-rules-7404e7a20282?sk=v2%2Fbd4f27c1-828a-4dd9-a7b7-05531295dd11)
. (Elaine Hilides (https://medium.com/u/3402a4a6f423)
)
I love this ode to minuscule, make-or-break details (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-N3xgmuvs2G?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
 by software engineer John Salvatier: "The more difficult your mission, the more details there will be that are critical to understand for success."

🧠 Your daily dose of practical wisdom
Everything you write deserves three rounds of edits. The first round is for you, second round is for your fans, and third round is for your haters. (Neil Strauss (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-LbtbJQohqr?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
 via Tony Stubblebine (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-WHDsj7yVsI?source=email-db17dc34be24-1733824530938-newsletter.v3-15f753907972-ae53b2a22bf2-----------------------a0169f9a_6de7_47ea_ba53_c79d17be2e9b--------bf3f56c7deec)
)

···

22.subject: Valid Palindrome
22.body:
[The Daily Byte](http://thedailybyte.dev)

Good morning,

Need help with yesterday's problem? [Start getting solutions.](http://thedailybyte.dev/plan#email=clutterfreemailtest@gmail.com)

Today's Byte

This question is asked by Facebook. Given a string, return whether or not it forms a palindrome ignoring case and non-alphabetical characters.

Note: a palindrome is a sequence of characters that reads the same forwards and backwards.

Ex: Given the following strings...
"level", return true
"algorithm", return false
"A man, a plan, a canal: Panama.", return true

Thanks,
The Daily Byte

23.subject: We saw a demo of the new AI system powering Anduril’s vision for war
23.sender: The Download from MIT Technology Review <newsletters@technologyreview.com>
23.body:
How to use Sora, OpenAI’s new video generating tool

In partnership with Rocket Software (https://www.rocketsoftware.com/?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID)
https://ter.li/TR10SneakPeek-Download25?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID
Subscribe & Save 25% (https://ter.li/TR10SneakPeek-Download25?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID)


**
The Download
------------------------------------------------------------


** Your daily dose of what’s up in emerging technology
------------------------------------------------------------


** By Rhiannon Williams • 12.10.24
------------------------------------------------------------

Hello! Today: how Anduril’s new AI system could change the future face of warfare. Plus: how to get started with OpenAI’s Sora video tool, and why US regulators are coming after the AI industry.
https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/12/10/1108354/we-saw-a-demo-of-the-new-ai-system-powering-andurils-vision-for-war/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-10-2024&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID


** We saw a demo of the new AI system powering Anduril’s vision for war
------------------------------------------------------------

—James O’Donnell

One afternoon in late November, I visited a weapons test site in the foothills east of San Clemente, California operated by Anduril, a maker of AI-powered drones and missiles that recently announced a partnership with OpenAI.

I went there to witness a new system it’s expanding today, which allows external parties to tap into its software and share data in order to speed up decision-making on the battlefield.

If it works as planned over the course of a new three-year contract with the Pentagon, it could embed AI more deeply than ever before into the theater of war. Read the full story (https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/12/10/1108354/we-saw-a-demo-of-the-new-ai-system-powering-andurils-vision-for-war/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-10-2024&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) .
https://ter.li/TR10SneakPeek-Download25?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID


** How to use Sora, OpenAI’s new video generating tool
------------------------------------------------------------

OpenAI has just released its video generation model Sora to the public. The announcement yesterday came on the fifth day of the company’s “shipmas” event, a 12-day marathon of tech releases and demos. Here’s what you should know—and how you can use the video model right now (https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/12/09/1108309/how-to-use-sora-openais-new-video-generating-tool/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-10-2024&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

—James O’Donnell

This story is the latest in MIT Technology Review’s How To (https://www.technologyreview.com/tag/how-to?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-10-2024&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) series, which helps you get things done.


** AI’s hype and antitrust problem is coming under scrutiny
------------------------------------------------------------

The AI sector is plagued by a lack of competition and a lot of deceit—or at least that’s one way to interpret the latest flurry of actions taken in Washington.

The actions—from antitrust investigations to accusations of straight-up lying—represent an effort to hold the AI industry’s hype to account in the final months before the Federal Trade Commission’s chair, Lina Khan, is replaced when Donald Trump takes office.

But while the FTC looks to have a far smoother transition of leadership ahead than most other federal agencies, at least some of Trump’s frustrations with Big Tech could send antitrust efforts in a distinctly new direction. Read the full story (https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/12/10/1108141/ais-hype-and-antitrust-problem-is-coming-under-scrutiny/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-10-2024&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

—James O’Donnell

This story is from The Algorithm, our weekly newsletter giving you the inside track on all things happening in the fascinating field of AI. Sign up (https://forms.technologyreview.com/newsletters/ai-demystified-the-algorithm/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-10-2024&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) to receive it in your inbox every Monday.
ADVERTISEMENT
Sponsored by Rocket Software (https://www.rocketsoftware.com/?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) https://www.rocketsoftware.com/?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://www.rocketsoftware.com/blogs/think-your-mainframe-secure-think-again?utag_name=2024_Q4_Global_C_Cross_NA_Awr_DP_MIT_3P_MITTechReviewNewsletter&utm_medium=DP&utm_source=MIT&utm_content=wbpg&utm_offer=NA&utm_term=NotApplicable&utm_campaign=2024_Q4_Global_CRS_pm_NA_evergreen&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID

Your mainframe security might not be as strong as it seems. With 91% of mainframe organizations reporting data breaches in the last 5 years, it’s clear no system is invincible. The risks — from configuration flaws to insider threats — are real, but so are the solutions.

Learn why mainframe security matters, how to catch code vulnerabilities early, and why multifactor authentication is a must. Prioritize your mainframe security now, before a breach costs you customers, revenue, and trust.

Act now (https://www.rocketsoftware.com/blogs/think-your-mainframe-secure-think-again?utag_name=2024_Q4_Global_C_Cross_NA_Awr_DP_MIT_3P_MITTechReviewNewsletter&utm_medium=DP&utm_source=MIT&utm_content=wbpg&utm_offer=NA&utm_term=NotApplicable&utm_campaign=2024_Q4_Global_CRS_pm_NA_evergreen&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID)


** The must-reads
------------------------------------------------------------
I’ve combed the internet to find you today’s most fun/important/scary/fascinating stories about technology.

1 Google has built a powerful new quantum computing chip
But it doesn’t have any real-world applications—yet. (Bloomberg (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2024-12-09/google-unveils-new-quantum-computer-with-mind-boggling-speed?sref=E9Urfma4&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)
+ It takes five minutes to solve a problem that a traditional supercomputer could not master in 10 septillion years. (NYT (https://www.nytimes.com/2024/12/09/technology/google-quantum-computing.html?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)
+ It’s a challenge the quantum field has been trying to crack for decades. (The Guardian (https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2024/dec/09/google-unveils-mindboggling-quantum-computing-chip?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) )
+ We covered the work when it was a preprint in September. (MIT Technology Review (https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/09/11/1103828/google-says-its-made-a-quantum-computing-breakthrough-that-reduces-errors/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-10-2024&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) )

2 Nvidia is being investigated by China
It claims the chipmaking giant has violated anti-monopoly laws. (BBC (https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/cx2vkd90mk8o?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) )
+ Nvidia’s biggest customer in the country? ByteDance. (Insider (https://www.businessinsider.com/bytedance-now-biggest-buyer-nvidia-ai-chips-china-tech-tiktok-2024-12?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)
+ What’s next in chips. (MIT Technology Review (https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/05/13/1092319/whats-next-in-chips/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-10-2024&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) )

3 TikTok has asked a US appeals court to halt the buy-or-sell law
As it stands, the app faces a ban unless it finds a new owner by January 19. (TechCrunch (https://techcrunch.com/2024/12/09/bytedance-tiktok-ask-appeals-court-to-temporarily-block-sell-or-ban-law/?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) )

4 AI is still failing to deliver on its economic promises
Is 2025 the year we finally start to see some results? (Quartz (http://qz.com/ai-agents-chatbots-artificial-intelligence-work-1851714587?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) )
+ The US AI industry is in desperate need of more sites with power grid access. (FT (https://www.ft.com/content/18576949-34c5-4822-b237-964debc1b1f4?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)
+ How to fine-tune AI for prosperity. (MIT Technology Review (https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/08/20/1096733/how-to-fine-tune-ai-for-prosperity/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-10-2024&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) )

5 The EU’s competition rules are on the verge of a big shakeup
A new boss means a new approach. (WSJ (https://www.wsj.com/world/europe/eus-new-competition-chief-plans-policy-overhaul-2d8ce43d?mod=tech_lead_story&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)
+ European regulators want to get to the bottom of a Meta and Google investigation. (FT (https://www.ft.com/content/fac060e0-4778-4ea6-a040-12bb7bf75806?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)

6 Weight-loss drugs are making basic health truths obsolete
A healthy diet and regular exercise is falling by the wayside. (The Atlantic (https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2024/12/diet-exercise-ozempic/680909/?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)
+ Weight-loss injections have taken over the internet. But what does this mean for people IRL? (MIT Technology Review (https://www.technologyreview.com/2023/03/20/1070037/weight-loss-injections-societal-impact-ozempic/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-10-2024&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) )

7 This bionic leg is controlled by its wearer’s brain
Prosthetic limbs are becoming much more capable. (New Yorker (https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2024/12/16/a-bionic-leg-controlled-by-the-brain?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)
+ These prosthetics break the mold with third thumbs, spikes, and superhero skins. (MIT Technology Review (https://www.technologyreview.com/2023/02/10/1067838/prosthetics-that-break-the-mold/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-10-2024&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) )

8 An AI can make a pretty decent Tokyo travel companion
Just make sure you take its advice with a pinch of salt. (Wired (https://www.wired.com/story/48-hours-in-tokyo-with-my-ai-travel-companion/?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)
+ How to use AI to plan your next vacation. (MIT Technology Review (https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/07/08/1094733/how-to-use-ai-to-plan-your-next-vacation/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-10-2024&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) )

9 Reddit is testing a new AI search feature
Which the site’s users are unlikely to take kindly to. (Ars Technica (https://arstechnica.com/ai/2024/12/reddit-debuts-ai-powered-discussion-search-but-will-users-like-it/?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) )

10 Jeff Bezos has a dinner with Donald Trump in his diary
Sounds cozy. (Insider (https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-jeff-bezos-donald-trump-feud-relationship-history-2024-11?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) $)


** Quote of the day
------------------------------------------------------------
------------------------------------------------------------


** “It’s like manna from heaven.”
------------------------------------------------------------
—Ari Morcos, chief executive of startup DatologyAI, explains to the Wall Street Journal (https://www.wsj.com/tech/ai/reddit-ai-partnerships-investors-59eef0fe?mod=tech_lead_pos1&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) why Reddit’s troves of text are so appealing to AI companies.


** The big story
------------------------------------------------------------
https://www.technologyreview.com/2022/10/24/1061064/book-review-animal-minds/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-10-2024&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID


** Inside the enigmatic minds of animals
------------------------------------------------------------

October 2022

More than ever, we feel a duty and desire to extend empathy to our nonhuman neighbors. In the last three years, more than 30 countries have formally recognized other animals—including gorillas, lobsters, crows, and octopuses—as sentient beings.

A trio of books from Ed Yong, Jackie Higgins, and Philip Ball detail creatures’ rich inner worlds and capture what has led to these developments: a booming field of experimental research challenging the long-standing view that animals are neither conscious nor cognitively complex. Read the full story (https://www.technologyreview.com/2022/10/24/1061064/book-review-animal-minds/?utm_source=the_download&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=the_download.unpaid.engagement&utm_term=&utm_content=12-10-2024&mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

—Matthew Ponsford


** We can still have nice things
------------------------------------------------------------

A place for comfort, fun and distraction to brighten up your day. (Got any ideas? Drop me a line (mailto:rhiannon.williams@technologyreview.com)  or skeet 'em at me (https://bsky.app/profile/rhiannonwilliams.bsky.social?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) .)

+ It seems we have two types of laugh (https://www.economist.com/science-and-technology/2024/11/20/the-two-types-of-human-laugh?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) : one caused by tickling, and the other by everything else.
+ 2024 was a strong year for fiction: check out some of the best new books (https://www.theguardian.com/books/2024/dec/07/the-best-fiction-of-2024?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) .
+ There’s something totally mesmerizing about this collection (https://walzr.com/IMG_0001?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) of old home videos.
+ Ukrainian artist Oleg Dron specializes in expansive, haunting landscapes (https://www.instagram.com/nordhelo/?mc_cid=fbbf3fb90d&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

24.subject: 😸 Facebook parents aren't ready
24.body:
With great launches come great crashes

Product Hunt ( https://www.producthunt.com/?utm_campaign=35865_2024-12-10&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=Daily+Digest )

Tuesday, Dec 10
The Leaderboard

gm legends! Welcome back to the Leaderboard. In today's
edition we're discussing Sora, OpenAI's video model that is
finally available to the public, a Tamagotchi for developers, and
a way to avoid those awkward meeting starts. Let's dive in.

With great launches come great crashes ( )

Sora: ( https://www.producthunt.com/posts/sora-4?utm_campaign=35865_2024-12-10&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=Daily+Digest&utm_term=editorial ) OpenAI's video generation model is now live

Sora — OpenAI’s text-to-video generation model —dropped yesterday
to great fanfare and, predictably, great crashes due to
overwhelming traffic. There’s lots of interesting stuff to unpack
here regarding the underlying tech, the potential
political/social implications (prepare for deepfakes galore)
but…can we just momentarily marvel at the fact that we now live
in a world where, for a relatively small fee, anyone can generate
dozens of feature length films by themselves and armed only with
a screenplay? What a time to be alive. I hope we still have some
screenwriters out there with good taste. I’m ready for a New New
Wave

Sanjana Friedman ( https://www.producthunt.com/@sanjanaf )

Sanjana Friedman
Head of Content @ Product Hunt ( https://www.producthunt.com/@sanjanaf )

Tamagotchi for developers ( )

GitAnimals: ( https://www.producthunt.com/posts/gitanimals?utm_campaign=35865_2024-12-10&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=Daily+Digest&utm_term=editorial ) Nuture a pet through GitHub contributions

Not going to lie, I've been putting off some of my side projects
for a bit. But when I saw GitAnimals ( https://www.producthunt.com/posts/gitanimals?utm_campaign=35865_2024-12-10&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=Daily+Digest&utm_term=editorial ), I took a few seconds out of my day to get my own little pet on
my GitHub page... and well... now 10 commits later I can say the
little furrball got me motivated. I didn't want to keep its level
at 0 and after every 30 commits I get to adopt a new pet! There's
a reason Tamagotchi works well, it's the cuteness combined with
nurturing your own little critter that makes you want to put in
the extra work, and this might be what gets me to launch more
before 2024 ends.

Gabe Perez ( https://www.producthunt.com/@gabe )

Gabe Perez
Head of Product Curation @ Product Hunt ( https://www.producthunt.com/@gabe )

No more awkward meetings ( )

icebreakers: ( https://www.producthunt.com/posts/icebreakers-b45694ac-4bea-4ec9-870f-67a447107f26?utm_campaign=35865_2024-12-10&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=Daily+Digest&utm_term=editorial ) A place to find icebreaker questions for meetings.

I’ve tried several interactive icebreaker apps that supposedly
integrate with Zoom, but they are clunky and requires each person
on the team to add the app and opt in so have given up on this.
Icebreakers is a low friction, clean and minimal design - love
that I can just pull it up on the web, instead of having to open
it up and log into a separate app. Would be awesome if Zoom or
google hangouts would incorporate something like this natively!
If you’re looking for a no frills icebreaker webpage to pull up,
this works well! But if looking for a more seamless all in one -
I’d give Butter ( https://www.producthunt.com/products/butter-e8a2b9c4-ea5f-4d20-92f0-c8ef4ae75bd1?utm_campaign=35865_2024-12-10&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=Daily+Digest&utm_term=editorial ) a go.

Leeann Trang ( https://www.producthunt.com/@ph_leeanntrang )

Leeann Trang
Operations @ Product Hunt ( https://www.producthunt.com/@ph_leeanntrang )
